page.title: 11ECOLOGY - Lydham/More
page.content: WILDLIFE ECOLOGY - Heath Mynd{upland {Common;}unimproved pasture and meadows at Upper Bent and More Village; banks of West Onny river; disused Lydham mill-leet; a tributary of Camlad river forms a pool at Bromleysmill. Also pools at Newton;Church Farm, More; and a lake at Linley Hall formed by a dam to West Onny.{Broadleaved woodland fragments remain at Roveries, lower slopes of Heath Mynd, s.e. tip of Big Wood, south corner of Hayes Wood, Lin- ley. 3960 feet of double{oak avenue leads to Linley Hall. Planted in 1938, this replaces the ancient oaks felled compulsorily in 1916. Many gardens in Lydham and More are natural habitats for wild birds, plants, butterflies, insects and mammals. Some{hedges}have been removed during last 20 years; many remain though some cut to 3 feet by mechanical hedgers.
